alert.note: Alert for Dearborn; Fayette; Franklin; Ohio; Ripley; Switzerland; Union (Indiana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued May 25 at 7:22PM EDT by NWS Wilmington
info.description: ...STRONG THUNDERSTORMS WILL IMPACT PORTIONS OF OHIO, FRANKLIN AND EASTERN RIPLEY COUNTIES IN SOUTHEASTERN INDIANA, UNION COUNTY IN EAST CENTRAL INDIANA, DEARBORN COUNTY IN SOUTHEASTERN INDIANA, SOUTHEASTERN FAYETTE COUNTY IN EAST CENTRAL INDIANA, NORTHWESTERN SWITZERLAND COUNTY IN SOUTHEASTERN INDIANA, NORTHERN BOONE COUNTY IN NORTHERN KENTUCKY, WESTERN HAMILTON AND BUTLER COUNTIES IN SOUTHWESTERN OHIO THROUGH 815 PM EDT... At 722 PM EDT, strong thunderstorms were located along a line extending from Batesville to 8 miles north of Vevay, moving northeast at 55 mph. HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph, half inch hail, frequent cloud-to-ground lightning, and very heavy rain. SOURCE...Radar indicated. IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Hail may cause minor damage to outdoor objects. Lightning can cause serious injury or death. Visibility will be poor and hydroplaning is possible. Locations impacted include... Cincinnati, Hamilton, Fairfield, Oxford, Forest Park, Connersville, Springdale, Harrison, North College Hill, Wyoming, Cheviot, Batesville, Mount Healthy, Lawrenceburg, Greendale, Aurora, Brookville, Rising Sun, Bright and Hidden Valley. This includes the following Interstates... I-74 in Indiana between mile markers 145 and 171. I-74 in Ohio between mile markers 0 and 19. I-75 in Ohio between mile markers 4 and 7. MAX HAIL SIZE...0.50 IN MAX WIND GUST...40 MPH
info.instruction: If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a sturdy building. Motorists should slow down and use extra caution. When thunder roars, go indoors! Do not stay in the open or seek shelter under trees when lightning threatens. Residents in these areas should remain alert. If these storms become stronger, then a warning may be needed. To report hazardous weather conditions, go to our website at weather.gov/iln and submit your report via social media, when you can do so safely.
